comment: Readily available in commerce.  Excellent groundcover for slopes or under pine trees.  Important plant to Native Americans.

One of our very best evergreen native groundcovers for shade and partial shade. Fragrant yellow flowers in late spring are followed by clusters of purple berries later in the summer. Drought resistant/drought tolerant plant (xeric).  Native to the Rocky Mountains and western North America.  It is deer resistant, and bees love it.
Wild buckwheats are very important to pollinators.   This one is one of our locals, a lover of very rocky sites.
Native throughout the west, Douglas’ buckwheat grows regionally in the western part of the Columbia Basin.  Small, narrow leaves.

Native to the western US.  Large clusters of creamy white flowers grace low shubs with narrow, frosty-green leaves.  8- 14” tall, 1-3’ wide.  Fully hardy in this area.  Grows in sagebrush steppe, dry open Ponderosa pine forest, and on dry, rocky soils.

Snow buckwheat is native to the Pacific Northwest.  A great plant for restoration and for xeriscapes.  Like all buckwheats, important for native pollinators: utilized by the rare Mormon metalmark butterfly.
This buckwheat is common in NE Oregon.  Pale sea green leaves have white-wooly undersides.  Variable over its western range:  generally low-growing with light yellow flower clusters.

flower-color: white, cream, sometimes pink, yellow, red
comment: Small, slow growing, very showy flowering shrublet of basalt substrates.  Once known as Ming tree - a bonsai subject.  Collector's item - somewhat difficult to keep.
One of many varieties and subspecies of Sulphur Flower Buckwheat.  This one, from the mountains in Ferry County, WA,  is an outstanding ground cover for an occasionally watered area.
Hardy English lavender does well in dry gardens.  Fragrant flowers have many uses, and are loved by bees.  Goldfinches eat the seeds.

Oregon boxleaf is a shiny, low-statured shrub, 8 in.- 2 ft. high, with small, glossy, dark-green leaves arrayed in pairs along ascending branches. It has  tiny, maroon flowers and evergreen leaves -attractive both in summer and winter.

Officially rare in the wild, but easy to cultivate.  Native only to the area in and around the Columbia River Gorge.  Outstanding landscape plant.  Evergreen shrub about 6 - 12 inches tall by 3 - 4  ft. wide.  Long lived.
One of the very best of the locals.  Showy year-round.  Likes rocky sites.  May spread up to 3 ft.  Long lived in the landscape.
Outstanding ground cover or rock garden plant.  Frequently pink flowered, with bluish foliage Very beautiful year-round.  Not common in commerce.  Long lived in the landscape.
Very showy early summer bloomer.  Good for pollinators.  Some traditional medicinal uses.  Important to Native Americans.
Thousands of species exist, native to Europe.  Great plants for dry, rocky areas or green roofs.
Forest shrub:  not a desert plant - likes occasional watering.  Very showy and attractive to different pollinators.
Great groundcover for dry areas, although it is not a native plant.  Lawn substitute for areas with light foot traffic.
